description: Perspectives on the impact that the Scandinavian raiders and traders popularly referred to as â€œVikingsâ€ had on European and World history continue to develop as the work of historians, archaeologists, linguists, and scientists expands our understanding of the past. Recent research has revised the traditional view of the â€œVikingsâ€ as primarily marauding warriors; in its place, a more complex and nuanced conception of the implications that â€œViking activityâ€ had on the social, economic, and political development of the peoples with whom they came in contact has emerged. This seminar will consider the relationship between the traditional conception of the â€œViking warriorâ€ and recent research that suggests the broader impact that the â€œViking Phenomenonâ€ had upon the economic revival and sociopolitical development of medieval Europe and its frontiers. In the course of the seminar, we will examine a selection of historical records and information concerning artifacts of the material culture of â€œThe Viking Ageâ€ in order to better understand the activities of early medieval â€œVikings,â€ not only as warriors, but also as agents of commerce, explorers, pioneers, and rulers. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
